results.title: Late in a wilderness

results.title: Late for dinner: was Dawn right?
results.creator_credit: Encyclopaedia Britannica Films and Gary Bergland
results.brief_description: Dawn, an Afro-American aged around eight, and her two friends have gone to play in the park. Dawn’s mother has told her it is very important she is home on time for dinner and stresses for her not to be late. However on her way home, Dawn collides with a woman running to catch a bus and in the confusion the woman drops a five-dollar bill. The woman boards her bus before Dawn can return the money. Dawn attempts to catch up with the bus but fails and consequently she arrives home late for dinner with money that doesn’t belong to her. Before she can explain, her mother begins to scold her - “Why are you late?” Helps children see that conflicting feelings are both common and normal. Set in the tenament area of Chicago. Part of the “How does it make you feel?” series. Suitable for middle and upper primary levels.

results.title: Late at night
results.creator_credit: Bruton Film Studios, Nettlefold Studios and Michael C. Chorlton
results.brief_description: A London reporter investigates an organised crime ring. Stars Barry Morse; Noel Dryden; Daphne Day; Paul Demel; John Rae; Frank Atkinson; Dennis Harkin; Clifford Cobbe; Ben Williams; Claire Smith; Bill Holland; and Beryl Trent. Story and screenplay by Henry C. James; song ‘Late at Night’ by Arthur Young; musical direction by Arthur Young.

results.title: Latcho drom : safe journey = Latcho drom : bonne route
results.creator_credit: K G Productions, Michele Ray-Gavras and Tony Gatlif
results.brief_description: A masterpiece by Tony Gatlif is a “docu-musical” which explores the rich cultural, social heritage of the world’s Gypsies. The program is a political statement about the persecution suffered by Gypsies but is presented as a celebration of their music, dance and song from the around the globe. Singers, dancers and musicians from India, Egypt, Turkey, Romania, Hungary, Slovakia, France and Spain are featured. This is an energetic, powerful, joyous experience.

results.title: Last stands: Tasmania
results.creator_credit: Island Films, Phil Lohrey and David Woodhall
results.brief_description: The last stands of temperate rainforests in Tasmania. Examines the issues of the geology of the forest, the problems posed by hydroelectric schemes and logging operations.

results.title: Last stand at Saber River
results.creator_credit: Warner Bros Pictures, Turner Entertainment, Mary Ann Braubach, Thomas Kane, Steven Brandman and Dick Lowry
results.brief_description: An embittered Confederate soldier returns to his Arizona homestead after the end of the Civil War, only to find it occupied by pioneers sympathetic to the Union war effort. Desperate to rebuild the life he once knew, he is forced to re-consider his loyalties and join forces with his Union adversary to make a last stand for the one thing left worth fighting for - his family.

results.title: Last stand
results.creator_credit: Coalition for Denmark's Environment (W.A.), Claire Calzoni and Frank Rijavec
results.brief_description: Western Australia had 5% forest cover at settlement. In 150 years that has been reduced to just 1%. “Last Stand” is a critical examination of south Western Australia’s natural forest reserves and present forest practices which threatens the remaining ancient Karri Forests. It sounds a timely warning that whole areas af Australia’s wilderness will be lost to future generations if short term commercial gain is the sole criteria for their management.

results.title: Last resort [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: BBC Film Unit, Ruth Caleb and Pawel Pawlikowski
results.brief_description: The low key Last Resort is an offbeat love story set around a defunct British seaside holiday resort. Russian immigrant Tanya (Dina Korzun) arrives at Gatwick airport with her ten year old son Artiom (Artiom Strelinikov) to be reunited with her British fiance. When he doesn’t arrive the distressed Tanya rashly decides to claim political asylum in order to stay in the country. She is then taken to a refuge holding center situated in an abandoned holiday resort where she virtually becomes a prisoner. While detained she meets amusement arcade manager Alfie (Paddy Considine) an ex-crim who takes Tanya and her son under his wings. Soon enough an unlikely romance develops between the pair. Director Pawel Pawlikowski handles his material delicately eliciting some wonderful naturalistic performances from his leads. While cinematographer Ryszard Lenczewski adds to the melancholy nature of the film by giving the look of the once thriving fun park an eerie beauty. Cast includes Lindsey Honey, Dave Bean, Katie Drinkwater. Pawel Pawlikowski: Winner of the 2001 BAFTA award for the Most Promising Newcomer in British Film.

results.brief_description: An insight into the role and function of the Victorian Ombudsman through the dramatization of actual cases investigated by the Office. Includes an interview with the Ombudsman.

results.title: Last orders
results.creator_credit: MPB, Scala Productions, Winchester Films, Fred Schepisi and Elizabeth Robinson
results.brief_description: Effortlessly moving between World War II and contemporary London, “Last Orders” is a film about friendship, honour and familial ties. Jack Dodd’s three best friends, and his son (played by Ray Winstone), are taking his ashes from London to Margate for the burial that Jack has demanded. His wife, Amy (Helen Mirren), has refused to go along for the ride: her journey takes the form of bittersweet remembrance of the betrayals, joys and comforts which are part of a lifelong marriage. Schepisi creates a perfectly realistic evocation of both old age and the passionate desires and dreamings of youth. “Last Orders” is in fact a peculiar kind of road movie in which the most important part of the journey is across time, and one in which the characters and personalities of the travellers are much more important than the dour suburbia through which they travel. At the heart of the film is Michael Caine’s Oscar nominated performance as Jack Dodd but he is ably supported by a superlative cast of British character actors. By placing actors such as Caine, Tom Courtenay and David Hemmings in a film about aging, death and grief, Schepisi also creates a loving memorial to the golden age of British cinema - the tough working class films of the early sixties which smashed the genteel pretensions of an earlier British cinema (though gentility was to arise again in the period dramas which now form the backbone of British television). “Last Orders” is based on the award winning novel by Graham Swift.
